text: <extra_id_0> HMG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binds to GATA motifs : implications for an HPFH syndrome .
We have examined binding of the nuclear protein <extra_id_0> HMG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to the human gamma-globin promoter .

We find that <extra_id_0> HMG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binds preferentially to the more 3 ' of a pair of GATA motifs in the gamma-globin promoter ; this paired motif is bound by the erythroid factor <extra_id_0> GATA-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: A naturally occurring mutation ( -175 T-C ) in the area bound by <extra_id_0> HMG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> results in overexpression of gamma-globin in adult red blood cells ( HPFH ) and up-regulation of the gamma-globin promoter in in vitro expression assays ; <extra_id_0> HMG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> does not bind to this mutant sequence .

text: A survey of GATA motifs from other globin cis-elements demonstrates <extra_id_0> HMG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binding to most of them .

These findings implicate <extra_id_0> HMG-I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the HPFH phenotype ; we speculate that it may participate in the formation of multiprotein complexes that regulate globin gene expression .
